answers.answer: Wow, I'm soooooo glad that you went in to the hospt. and that they caught your sugar levels. yikees, that scary... did it do any permanent damage? I hope that the insulin will be easy to adapt to, and that you will be able to control it better.I just want to give you a great big ((((((hug)))))) and I hope that you do feel better both physically and emotionlly soon.~Sunnytoday~

Holy C rap Penns! To me, 400 is still off the charts, I've heard horror stories of higher, but 400 is dangerous.  I'm sorry you have to go in insulin, but this can cause you so much more damage than just feeling badly.Not that it changes anything, but I don't think they should of let you out of there w/out getting i down further to a more stable range. Or knowing for sure what has caused this to happen so suddenly.  Was the med you mention controlling it well until this?ttys,Shell

Thanks  so much for the moral support - I surely do need it.Sunnytoday - it's still that high. Just checked before coming in to peek at the forum and it was 412. It hasn't been lower than 335 at all. Nurse is coming tomorrow am.Shell - there was no other med - I did not have diabetes - that's why I was so shocked.  They said I developed it "a few weeks ago". My sugar had run too low much of my life actually.Penn

Oh, my GOODness!  What the heck!!?!!Is there any other body system you want to include in your maladies or are you about done for now?MAN!!  I know this had to be quite a shock to you, Penn, and I'm sorry you have this now to deal with, too.  Sheesh!  And you have your mother's history haunting you, too.  I'm so sorry.Does your internist know about all this?  Are they on board with the prescribed treatment?  Wow, it seems so drastic to go directly on insulin after never having been diagnosed with diabetes before, but, 456 IS pretty dagnab high!Let us know how it goes with the nurse, and hang tight, my friend.DH was a sweetie!Love and hugs,Zilla*

Hi Penn.  Glad to see you back on the forum but I am so very sorry about the diabetes and needing insulin.  I hope the nurse is nice tomorrow.Heather used to take drugs for diabetes and she will hopefully be here to help.I hope you don't have to go on leave from your job.  Are you able to use your sick time all up first before being forced to go out?  Or all of your vacation time?  I have gotten the impression in your previous posts that you get much satisfaction from your job, so I can imagine how upsetting it would be for you to have to go on leave.Keep in touch.Elaine

IT"S STILL THAT HIGH???? You HAVE let some-one know? RIGHT????? I mean, I know it can go higher, but I've heard stories of high levels damaging stuff, and we need you to be as healthy as possible. EEEKK!! Seiously though, that's scary stuff. I realllllly hope all your doctor's get their ducks in a row, you don't usually just 'develop' that kind of awful high levels in two or three weeks, not if they are sustaining like that. At least, that's not what i learned in school. course, i could have learned wrong, i'm no dr. :)Let us know what's going on, ok???~Sunnytoday~

I sooooo appreciate all of you - this is the best bunch of people anywhere.Unfortunately I am still pretty darned high - 390 this evening. The nurse (being sent through my PCP) will be here around 10 in the am. My DH picked up the insulin and syringes, etc so all is ready for her visit. i guess she'll be coming out for a week or so to get me going.I just don't understand why they discharged me when my sugar was not at all under control. Yes I know, I am not the ideal inpatient - I HATE hospitals. But it just seems poor judgement to discharge someone w/ those levels and tell them "oh, they'll keep going down" - not quite!Z - you are right - I think I have no body systems left to malfunction! Hoping the insulin is temporary though.Elaine - going on leave would kill me - being home now is killing me. I LOVE my job. all of our paid time off is lumped together. I am using it now, but will be out soon due to all the darn appointments, etc. Wrong year to take my first ever in my life weeks vacation I guess! I'd like to have those days abck now - oh well!Very tired - going to bed. Will let you know how the nurse visit goes.Penn

I am so sorry that you're having to use your paid time off on this!  That reaaalllly stinks!  I cannot believe the hospital dismissed you with levels practically the same as when you went in.I'll be thinking about you tomorrow and wishing you the best with the nurse and learning to use the syringes, honey.Have a good night's sleep.Deb
Going to be admitted back in hospital  this afternoon - leaving now. Thanks for the supportPenn

***Keeping this on top for Penns****I was just going to say something doesn't sound right about this whole deal.No warning signs, letting you out of the hospital like that..just all off.I'm so glad you are in the hospital by now (I hope) Penns.LOTS of Prayers for answers and a group of great Drs to figure this out for Penns!-Shell

Oh, no, late to the party and got more and more worried as I read down.  Now, just glad to hear they are going to take care of you.  Just exactly what you didn't need.  Please have DH keep us informed, not that he is a card-carrying member!Quix

I'm SOOOO glad Pen went back to the hospital, i was soooo worried. I was told in school it was dangerous to have your sugar levels stay that high, and I thought the hospital would be smart enough to know that and not just discharge her, right Quix?Penn, and DH, keep us up-to-date.... I'm rather worried here.~Sunnytoday~
bump
I'm hoping you're okay--glad you're going to be under close supervision at the hospital.  Thinking about you . . .Deb

Was just released form hospital. Sugar not quite controlled, but is coming down. It wasn't budging unitl last evening - had still been in mid to high 300's. This morning I was 231 - lowest I've been. HMOs want to get you out though, but this time there's more organization - endocrinologist in place, in home nurse again for a couple visits, had diabetes education and nutrition consult inpatient, and there's an actual plan for how to get to where I need to be.You'll have to excuse my typing - still can't see too well. Trying to correct as I catch them.I now have an insulin pen rather than the syringes. Tough to tell if you've pushed in enough to administer, but I'll get used to it. I was quite dehydrated (had ridiculous diarrhea for a few days prior to admit - had IV fluids the entire time I was there. The fluids knocked my electrolytes off balance, so I had IV calcium and magnesium too. I feel better.My doc said there are a handful of folks whose diabetes is just resistant to treatment, so naturally I would be one of those. Guess that's true since my levels didn't come down even in the hospital. Really I think being left swinging in the breeze had a lot to do with it too. It was good to see the portions that my meals came in there - gives me a better feel for what I can eat, which is more than I thought depending on what you choose to eat! I had been afraid to eat adn was hardly eating anything; guess that's not good either. This is tough, but I'll get the hang of it.My poor DH was running like a wild man and couldn't get near a computer. Running right form work to the hospital and then falling asleep as soon as he got home. Thank you all so much for thinking of me while I was there.Penn

Hi Penn!We were worried! So, they are saying that this is definitely diabetes huh? My gosh, seems you never saw this coming.  It's still high, and it's affecting your vision, I'm so sorry this is happening to you.I'm glad for it lowering but do wish they did not rush you out until it was lower and showed a day or 2 of staying stable.We certainly understand DH being whiped out over all the running.Still thinking of you and hope this re-organization of Drs stay on top of this for you!Feel well soon friend,Shell

This all amazes me!  You didn't see this creeping up on you at all, did you?  Do they think this is Type II?  Does it run in your family?All I could say was Oh, my!!For all, I strongly suspect that Penn's vision problem is from the high glucose.  that itself makes the vision blurry.  It would not be from retinal damage this soon after the disease showed up.  When the glucose comes down the blurriness should resolve.  Isn't that what they told you?You are in my thoughts, Kiddo!Quix

Yes, they are attributing the vision issue to the glucose levels. It is ok at times right now and bad at others. Though my sugar is by no means controlled yet. It was 366 before dinner today. I suspect my insuling dosages will change a few more times. doing the insulin is not nearly as horrendous as I expected - already getting used to it.Yes, I believe it is type II. My mother had it - dx'd at age 50ish.I wish my spasms and balance would take a vacation till this is under control - a lot to deal with all at once. I am starting to believe I can do it though. Keep telling myself He won't put more on me than I can bear (though I think He overestimates my load-bearing capabilities, lol;) also use thet that which doesn't kill you only makes you stronger -- my mantras, lol!Penn

Hon, I'm sorry, some how I missed this post. (hanging my head in shame)Sweetie you really have been through the wringer haven't you. I'm sorry about the diabetes. So are you still going to stay off work for a bit until you are a little more back on your feet?Maybe all this is telling you that you need to slow down a little? What am I thinking? You slow down? Never!! lolSeriously hon, take it easy for a bit right now.HugsMoki

yes it has been a heck of a year (almost 2 now actually). I'm dealing with it though. This really came out of left field - not a clue! Still trying to reign in the sugar levels - a little better this am. Hoping it will last more than one testing.I've already been off work for 2 weeks. Can't take it anymore. Gonna try to go back Wednesday if they'll let me. Home nurse comes again tomorrow - hopefully last time. Made appt with my opthamologist as still cannot see any better. I'm going to get a pair of cheapy reading glasses so I can see my computer at work but I'll not be able to drive yet. Soonest appt I could get was next Wednesday.Emailed neuro re update on balance issues - have that appt next week too (Thursday).So how are you doing?Penn

question: I wanted to thank everyone who answered my DH's first venture onto the forum!I did go to the ER on Sunday late (vision like through vasoline, WAY off balance, nausea) and was kept. I had thought "well maybe this will get me my repeat MRI". They took me straight back in a chair when they saw how badly I was struggling to stand.Ironically the far bigger issue was the combination of the vision and nausea (thought the nausea was due to the balance). They said the balance is the neuro issue and they'd leave it to Dr McDreamy as he's "the guru". My bloodwork showed sugar @ 456! I've had it checked regularly and its been normal as recently as a couple months ago. They said it was triggered by an infection, and I've probably had the hyperglycemia for a few weeks - about when my vision started to fade! Could've knocked me over with a feather.When I was released my sugar was only down to 350. Since then its been the same or somewhat worse, despite increasing my med (glucophage), then changing the med and increasing THAT one. Last night I hit 400, so I was told this am I have to go on insulin (caused a good cry - I remember my mother dealing w/ insulin). A nurse is coming tomorrow and a few more times to teach us how to inject. Worse thing is I do not know when I can go back to work and they're really pushing me to go on leave.I know in the grand scheme of things insulin is not that big a deal, but my mother was double dosed in the hospital when she was first diagnosed (I was in middle school) and nearly died. I'm sure they've gotten better since then:)Anyway, feeling crappy both physically and emotionally. Vision getting better though. Done whining now. When I feel a little better I need to get caught up on how all of you are doing... have missed you.Penn
